Here is a precise numerical problem on radioactive decay and half-life equations:

A sample of radon-222 has an initial mass of 64 grams. If the half-life of radon-222 is 3.823 days, how much of the sample will remain after 10 days? (Round your answer to the nearest tenth of a gram.)
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the radioactive decay formula:

Final mass = Initial mass * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial mass is 64 grams, the half-life is 3.823 days, and the time elapsed is 10 days.

Final mass = 64 * (1/2)^(10 / 3.823)

Final mass = 64 * (1/2)^(2.615)

Final mass = 64 * 0.191

Final mass â‰ˆ 12.2 grams

After 10 days, approximately 12.2 grams of the radon-222 sample will remain.
